manchego.title@en: Professor, head of the AI accountability lab

texts.text@en: Hi there, welcome to the newsroom!
I hear you're the new algorithmic accountability reporter.
Whatever that means.
I've got a tip for you.
Ever heard of TikTube?

feedback.text@en: Of course, it's the social app all teenagers are on.
You're not as clueless as I thought.
I'm afraid I haven't.
TikTube is the social media platform all teenagers are on.
Everyone in this newsroom knows that.

texts.text@en: I've heard that TikTube's algorithm is making teenagers sad.
Find out if that's true.

feedback.text@en: Thank you, I'll do my best.
You have 2 days.
Because you're new, I'm pairing you with our senior reporter on Artificial Intelligence.

texts.text@en: Hello colleague.
The editor-in-chief is tough, but she's fair.
... to people who give her good stories, at least.
You should start by asking the European Center for Algorithmic Transparency.
The European center for what?
Wait, let me write you an e-mail.
That's nice of you.
It'll be faster for me.
You might want to [check your inbox|ECAT] before you call.

feedback.text@en: Thanks, I'll read it attentively.

texts.text@en: Hello, what can I do for you?

choices.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?

feedback.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?

choices.text@en: Does TikTube's algorithm make teenagers sad?

feedback.text@en: Does TikTube's algorithm make teenagers sad?

texts.text@en: According to the Digital Services Act, ECAT is committed to shedding light on algorithms that impact European citizens.
We are building a team of many specialists for this task.
But I can't comment on specific cases.
However, you can ask TikTube for data access.

feedback.text@en: You didn't answer my question.
According to the Regulation 1049/2001, you can make a request for more information.
Thanks for contacting ECAT.
We wish you good luck in your reporting.

choices.text@en: How can I ask for access?

feedback.text@en: How can I ask for access?
According to the Digital Services Act, you simply need to team up with a researcher at a university.
Then make a request to your national Digital Services Coordinator.
They will forward it to the Irish Digital Services Coordinator, because TikTube is based in Ireland.
If the Irish agree, you'll be able to request the data from TikTube.
Thanks for contacting ECAT.
We wish you good luck in your reporting.

texts.text@en: How did it go at ECAT?

feedback.text@en: ECAT has no clue about TikTube.
Well, at least you tried.

choices.text@en: I couldn't get their spokesperson to talk.

feedback.text@en: I asked questions, but got nothing.
That's the point of many press officers.
Don't let them wear you down.

texts.text@en: How did it go at ECAT?

feedback.text@en: I'm afraid ECAT has no clue about TikTube.
Well, at least you tried.

choices.text@en: We should do a request for data access.

feedback.text@en: We should try to make a request for data access.
That mechanism will only start in mid-2024.
And you just have one day left.
What can I do, then?

texts.text@en: You should try to contact TikTube directly.
Be careful about their press officer.
He's a former journalist, I know him well.
Compared to him, ECAT's spokesperson is helpful.
I sent you an email with some tips, [check your inbox|revolvingDoor].

feedback.text@en: Thanks, your help is precious.

texts.text@en: Hi there! 👋🏼
I'm Otmar.
Call me Oti.
I'm a good friend of your colleague Lisbet's!
We used to work together.

choices.text@en: I'm trying to figure out how TikTube's algorithm works.

feedback.text@en: I'm trying to figure out how TikTube's algorithm works.
Can you help me?
Of course!
Our feed is personalized for each user.
The recommendations depend on a number of factors.
For instance, the content the user liked or commented on.
Or language preference, country setting, and device type.

choices.text@en: Does TikTube impact the mental health of its users?

feedback.text@en: Some people say TikTube is making teenagers sad.
Does TikTube impact the mental health of its users?
TikTube lets users create authentic content and entertain audiences far and wide.
When we come across content that may not be appropriate for the general public, we do our best to remove it from our recommendation system.
Thanks Oti, that's helpful!
Anytime ☺️
And say hi to Lisbet for me!
Can you be more precise?
For instance, are recommendations entirely personalized?
Or does the algorithm also use general parameters that apply to everyone?
TikTube’s recommendation system drops in diverse types of content along with those you already know you love.
That way you can enjoy your favorite videos and explore new topics.
Could this feature push too much depressing content, and make users sad?
If a user sees something that's not to their liking, they can click on 'not interested' to indicate that it does not suit their taste or interest.
Thanks for your interest ☺️
And say hi to Lisbet for me!
You haven't answered my question.
Bye!

choices.text@en: Have you conducted an audit of your algorithm?

feedback.text@en: Has TikTube conducted an audit of its algorithm?
We collaborate regularly with researchers.
Professor Alois Manchego will soon release a study which you will find interesting.
Thanks for your interest ☺️
And say hi to Lisbet for me!

texts.text@en: So, what have you got for me?
Are you ready to publish?

feedback.text@en: Not yet. I need more time.
I'll give you one more day.
Now go get to work.

choices.text@en: Yes. The headline: « Details of TikTube's algorithm REVEALED »

feedback.text@en: Yes.
I think the headline should be Details of TikTube's algorithm REVEALED.
What's your source for the revelations?
Oti... I mean Otmar Kadlec, TikTube's spokesperson.
Did you double check what he said?
I'm afraid I haven't.
I give you one more day, now go back to work!
Thank you, boss.

texts.text@en: Tell me, Lisbet, how do I check what Oti told me?
You should ask people who use TikTube.
What do they know about the algorithm?
Nothing, and many things.
Can you be more precise?
I don't have time now, but I'll send you an e-mail.
Make sure to check [your inbox|AlgorithmicImaginaries].
Do you know any teenagers?

feedback.text@en: Yes, I'll ask my nephew.
No.
Then just go to a high school and ask around.

texts.text@en: What do you want?
Do you use TikTube?
Is water wet?
I'll take that as a yes.
Does TikTube make you sad? People say it does.
Who says that? TikTube is just an app, it's funny.
It's not making anyone sad.

choices.text@en: It never shows you depressing videos?

feedback.text@en: It never shows you depressing videos?
Videos that you might not want to watch?
Sometimes.
I just swipe them away.
Does TikTube's algorithm ever surprise you?
What would be the point if it did not?
I thought journalists asked better questions.
Well... thanks anyway.
I'll leave now, you seem busy.

texts.text@en: Who's this?
Creeeepy...
What do you want?

feedback.text@en: Does any of you use TikTube?
Does fire burn?
Is the sky blue?
Ciao, bye.
I'm a journalist researching TikTube.
I'm trying to understand how the algorithm works.
What's your experience with it?
TikTube is just a lot of fun.
Nothing more.
The algorithm is SO EASY to crack.
Oh, really?
I'm in this Telegram group.
We like each other's posts.
So the algorithm thinks we're viral and pushes our videos even more.
Sometimes I feel the algorithm knows me too well.
It makes me uncomfortable.
Can you tell me more?
If you promise not to write my name.
Sure.
I promise.
It's like TikTube knows when I'm sad.
And then pushes videos that make me sadder.
Even when I tell the app to stop.
It doesn't.

texts.text@en: So, what have you got for me?

feedback.text@en: Not much, I need more time.
You have two more days.
Not more.

texts.text@en: So, what have you got for me?

feedback.text@en: Not much, I need more time.
You have two more days.
Not more.

choices.text@en: I'm ready to publish. The headline: « TikTube can harm teens »

feedback.text@en: I'm ready to publish.
The headline: TikTube can harm teens.
You have the front page.
<video width='320' height='320' autoplay><source src='images/endings/tiktube-harms-teens.mp4' type='video/mp4'>OK, published!</video>
Just one source.
That's not very serious journalism.
Your piece is ridiculous. 😑
If that teen you mention contacted you on TikTube...
I'll find them. 😈

choices.text@en: I'm ready to publish. The headline: « Teens can crack TikTube's algorithm »

feedback.text@en: I'm ready to publish.
The headline: Teens can crack TikTube's algorithm.
You have the front page.
<video width='320' height='320' autoplay><source src='images/endings/teens-can-crack-tiktubes-algorithm.mp4' type='video/mp4'>OK, published!</video>
Just one source.
That's not very serious journalism.
I like your piece a lot. 👏🏼
It shows that our users are fully in control.

texts.text@en: So, what have you got for me?

feedback.text@en: Not much, I need more time.
You have two more days.
Not more.

choices.text@en: I'm ready to publish. The headline: « Teenagers are happy with TikTube's algorithm »

feedback.text@en: I'm ready to publish.
The headline: Teenagers are happy with TikTube's algorithm.
You have the front page.
<video width='320' height='320' autoplay><source src='images/endings/teens-happy-with-tiktube.mp4' type='video/mp4'>OK, published!</video>
Wow, that's some poorly researched journalism.
You pretty much did PR work.
Brilliant, I love your piece! 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼
We need more journalists like you.

texts.text@en: Hi there.
I'm a former employee at TikTube.
I have some documents that might interest you.

feedback.text@en: Yes, please!

choices.text@en: Can you prove who you are?

feedback.text@en: Can you prove who you say you are?
Here's a screenshot of my e-mail inbox at TikTube.
Anyone could fake this.
You'll need to double-check anything they send.

choices.text@en: Not interested. That would be against the law on trade secrets.

feedback.text@en: Thanks, but I'll pass.
I'm afraid the law on trade secrets prevents me from accepting.
Thanks, will do.

texts.text@en: I was in the ethics team at TikTube.
We did research on our impact on mental health.
The team was disbanded in early 2023.
Here are some slides from an internal presentation I made last year.

feedback.text@en: Wow, that's heavy.
Thanks.

choices.text@en: Who can confirm that they're genuine?

feedback.text@en: How can I confirm that they're not fake?
A former colleague will contact you soon.
Lisbet, is that enough to check the veracity of the docs?
Two sources are better than one. Three better than two. You get the idea.
Pssst...
I've been told to contact you.
What you saw appears genuine.
You never talked to me.

texts.text@en: You've got yourself a nice scoop with this leak.

feedback.text@en: Thanks. Couldn't have done it without you.

texts.text@en: You still need to get some more context from academics working on algorithms.
Here are two specialists. Call one of them.

choices.text@en: Prof. Alois Manchego, head of the AI accountability lab

texts.text@en: Hello. I'm professor Manchego.
I created the AI accountability lab.
I've been called a leading authority in the field several times.

feedback.text@en: Does TikTube make teens sad?
As far as I know, there is only anecdotal evidence for this hypothesis.
My work tends to show that teens use TikTube to accomplish themselves.
I'll soon publish a major paper on teenage use of TikTube.
I'll add you to my mailing list.

choices.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?

feedback.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?
It's really complex.
I've been given exclusive access to TikTube.
I can tell you that these are expert people.
So, how does it work?
TikTube automatically assess a user's interests.
Then offers videos to match.
Thank you professor.
This is illuminating.

choices.text@en: Who finances the AI accountability lab?

feedback.text@en: Who finances the AI accountability lab?
We are funded by Google, Meta, Deutsche Bank and TikTube.
But we are 100% independent.
These companies are interested in the work we do.
And they recognize that I'm a leading authority in the field.
I'll now excuse myself.
I have to give an interview to CNN.

texts.text@en: Good morning, I'm Hiltrud Brandt.
I did a PhD on the social impact of automated systems.
I'm now a post-doctoral researcher.

feedback.text@en: Does TikTube make teens sad?

choices.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?

feedback.text@en: How does the TikTube algorithm work?

texts.text@en: Asking the question in this way might not be helpful.
TikTube is actually made of many parts.
There's a system to spot and block any pornography, for instance.
And another one to decide which ads to display.
And another one to recommend new accounts to follow.
And another one to decide which videos to show to a given user?
Exactly.

choices.text@en: Which of these systems should I investigate?

feedback.text@en: This is a question for you to answer.

texts.text@en: Not only are there many algorithms – plural.
They constantly interact with humans.
Be they users, people who tag videos to train Machine Learning models, executives who decide to chase a new goal...
It's impossible to give a precise description of how this system works.
It's simply too vast, too complex.
So, we'll never know if TikTube makes teens sad?
Oh, of course we can find out.
But you'll need to rephrase your question.
For one thing, teens have many reasons to be sad.
The climate catastrophe, the low wages...

choices.text@en: How does TikTube contribute to this?

feedback.text@en: You mean that TikTube doesn't compare?
This would be hard to find out.
You'd need to make a randomized controlled trial.
One group would use TikTube, one wouldn't, and you'd compare their mental health outcome.
But – thank goodness – no serious ethical review board would accept such an experiment.

choices.text@en: So, how do I rephrase my question?

feedback.text@en: So, what can I actually research?
You could conduct a small-scale audit.
To check whether TikTube gives priority to sad content, for instance.
If you create an account that posts sad content...
And another one that doesn't...
And ask people to follow both and report when they see your posts...
Then you would see how often sad content is shown.
Auditing algorithms is a complex thing. [I'll send you an email with more examples|AlgorithmicAudits].
Thanks, I'll talk to my colleagues.

texts.text@en: So, what's your headline?

choices.text@en: « Despite concerns, TikTube is mostly good for teens »

feedback.text@en: My story should be titled Despite concerns, TikTube is mostly good for teens.
You have the front page.
<video width='320' height='320' autoplay><source src='images/endings/tiktube-mostly-good.mp4' type='video/mp4'>OK, published!</video>
Nice story! 👍🏼
Well done.
But you should have put a picture of me on the front page.
Not for my ego, but to give more weight to your piece.
You know that Manchego's research is financed by TikTube, right?
I'm afraid I need more time, boss.
Listen, I'm running a newsroom.
Not a spa.
This algorithmic accountability beat is nothing for you.
From now on, you'll do post-editing on texts that have been automatically generated by ChatGPT.

Interesting story.
Nice story 👍🏼
TikTube is strongly in favor of sound regulation.

texts.text@en: Well done.
The editor-in-chief is rarely so generous.
It's all because of you.
To conduct your audit of TikTube, get in touch with Ant1G4F4m.
How to pronounce her name?
That's not the point.
She's a brilliant computer developer.

feedback.text@en: Thanks, will do.

texts.text@en: Hello, what can I do for you?
I'd like to carry out an audit of TikTube.
To know whether sad content is prioritized in the newsfeed.
And how shall we do this?
We set up two TikTube accounts.
One posts happy content, the other sad content.
Lots of users follow both.
And we check whether they see more posts from the happy or from the sad account.
These 'lots of users', are they real people or bots?

feedback.text@en: Real users.
OK, I assume you have months ahead of you?
Convincing people to participate is hard.
I have five days.
I'll create some bots, then.
But they might get blocked by TikTube.
Bots.
OK, but keep in mind that TikTube might detect them and block us.
I haven't thought of that.
I'd rather go with bots, it's much faster.
But TikTube might block us.

texts.text@en: I'll get started now.
And get back to you in a few days.

feedback.text@en: Thanks, looking forward.

texts.text@en: Hello again 👋🏼
I've seen that you have a project going on.
That's great! 👍🏼 We love external researchers.
Thanks!
But this particular project of yours is going against our Terms of Service.
Our lawyers will be happy to support you to make it compliant. 🫱🏼
But you'll need to shut down your project first.

feedback.text@en: Oh, I apologize.
No harm done! 😊
We'll soon be in touch to help you.
I guess you'll have to review your Terms of Service.
Because I'm keeping my project on.
You could land in trouble.
Your bluff does not work on me.

texts.text@en: Here are the results.
It's really exciting.
The odds of seeing a video that shows sad content over the odds of seeing any video from our test accounts is 3.2!
Could you repeat in plain English please?
Based on our data, TikTube does prioritize sad content, a lot.
Of course, we did it with bots, and the behavior of real users could be different.
It's still solid evidence that something fishy is going on.
So.
How's that audit going?
The story will soon be ready.
The headline should be New evidence that TikTube prioritizes sad content.
You have the front page.
<video width='320' height='320' autoplay><source src='images/endings/tiktube-prio-sad-content.mp4' type='video/mp4'>OK, published!</video>
Very nice piece, well done.
Interesting findings.
I'll cite you in my next paper.
I just read your story.
Would you be interested in giving a workshop at ECAT?
We strongly dispute your findings.
Why are you staring at your screen like that?
I'm waiting for an email from TikTube.
They promised they'd help me if I stopped my audit.
You trusted them?
Seriously?
Did I make a mistake?
So.
How's that audit going?
Well...
Can I start over?
Listen, I'm running a newsroom.
Not a preschool.
This algorithmic accountability beat is nothing for you.
From now on, you'll do post-editing on texts that have been automatically generated by ChatGPT.

endings.text@en: You did not crack TikTube's algorithm, but it's unlikely anyone can.

Congratulations

You did not crack TikTube's algorithm, but now you know that it makes no sense to talk of cracking an algorithm.

You did, however, bring new facts to the public, which will help users and decision-makers better understand how large platforms work.

ECAT.title@en: Subject: The European Center for Algorithmic Transparency
ECAT.body@en:
Hello colleague,

As I told you, here's a short helper about ECAT.

ECAT opened in April 2023 in Sevilla, Spain. It should grow to 30 people by 2024. They shall support European regulators in their investigations of automated systems.

AlgorithmWatch wrote an explainer about it: https://algorithmwatch.org/en/dsa-explained/.

Cheers,

Lisbet

revolvingDoor.body@en:
Hi there,

Large tech companies have a thing European journalists don't: money. They hired lots of former journalists to carry out their lobbying. They will sweet-talk you into believing everything they say.

Stay alert, and don't fall for their tricks. Every piece of information you get from them must be verified, or at least veryfiable. Pay attention when they use the conditional tense, or say that their algorithm might, or may, or could do a certain thing. We need certainty.

Cheers,

Lisbet

AlgorithmicImaginaries.body@en:
Hi colleague,

People who use or are subjected to automated systems don't have access to the black boxes anymore than you do. But they have plenty of experience.

Sometimes, they do manage to pull out actions based on it, like when TikTokers managed to sink a far-right event in 2020 by fake-registering then not showing up.

But most of the time, this hands-on knowledge is fleeting. One YouTuber thought he'd cracked the TikTok algorithm, for instance, only to later realize that he had not.

This is what academics call algorithmic imaginaries: What people think about an automated system. Even if the beliefs of users are not based in fact, these beliefs exist and must be taken into account in your reporting.

Cheers,

Lisbet

AlgorithmicAudits.body@en:
Dear journalist,

I enjoyed talking to you earlier.

Auding an automated system is actually much more than running computer code. You need to understand how the system works in relation with the people who operate it, and the people who use it.

Academics call these kinds of investigation "mixed-methods", which are a combination of qualitative and quantitative techniques.

AlgorithmWatch wrote a good piece on the topic: How researchers are upping their game to audit recommender systems.

Good luck with your investigation,

Dr. Brandt
